Award.AwardTitle: Singularities in Oscillatory Integrals, Inverse Problems and Transformation Optics
Award.AbstractNarration:
This proposal deals with four distinct problems having the unifying theme of controlling, estimating or reconstructing singularities that arise in oscillatory and Fourier integral operators and inverse problems, as well as the opposite goal of using singularities to obtain new designs in the emerging field of transformation optics. The first problem concerns optimal decay estimates for oscillatory integral operators in two dimensions. In the second, degenerate versions of the Carleson-Sjolin estimates will be pursued. The third project involves a linearized inverse problem for wave equations arising in seismic imaging which leads to analysis and composition of degenerate Fourier integral operators. Finally, analysis on singular spaces will be used to understand the theoretical limits to cloaking and other transformation optics designs.

Progress on these problems will add to the understanding of partial differential equations, the operators which are used to solve them, and the behavior of their solutions. Many laws of nature are expressed as partial differential equations, which govern physical quantities of interest, such as electromagnetic field strength, pressure exerted by acoustic waves or the quantum-mechanical probability that a particle will be found in a particular place. The techniques to be developed in this project are applicable to equations that govern various kinds of wave propagation and are based on a geometric point of view in understanding and manipulating the singularities which are present. In particular, the third project has the potential to facilitate seismic exploration in situations where images are distorted by the presence of multiple rays connecting seismic source to receiver. The fourth project concerns theoretical underpinnings of the recently emergent field of transformation optics, which has the potential to produce unusual effects on various kinds of waves (e.g., electromagnetic, acoustic, quantum mechanical) using artificially structured materials known as metamaterials.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project had several distinct components. All involved understanding issues in mathematical analysis and mathematical physics in situations where there is some kind of singularity, broadly understood. In the presence of singularities, which can come about either in technological settings, where artificial materials have highly unusual properties which change over very short length scales, or natural settings, where, for example, the speed of acoustic (sound) waves moving through the Earth undergoes a jump across a sedimentary layer.  Alternatively, a smoothly varying sound- or light-speed in a medium can cause rays to overlap and accumulate, producing singularities called caustics. New analytical techniques need to be developed to deal with singularities, but they also present a potential source of  new phenomena to be exploited.

Transformation optics is an emerging area that uses ideas from geometry to describe physical parameters of a medium, such as sound speed or index of refraction (which controls the speed at which light travels), that have radical effects on wave propagation. One of the most extreme of these effects is cloaking, which (theoretically) shields a region of space from observation using some kind of wave (optical, microwave, electric, etc.). Perfect cloaks are beyond the reach of current technology, but approximate cloaks have been implemented for various kinds of waves.

Radon transforms form the basis for CT medical  imaging. Generalized Radon transforms occur both in applied and theoretical settings and have been studied for decades. Multilinear generalized Radon transforms are a much newer concept and much of the work supported by this Project concerned trying to control their singularities in a way that would be useful within mathematics.

Intellectual merit:  The PI has previously studied both perfect transformation optics designs and their more realistic approximate implementations. This Project supported further work on exploiting resonances of approximate cloaks to obtain theoretical designs and numerical simulations  (which we called `Schroedinger hats') capable of capturing passing waves, amplifying and storing them for long periods. It also supported research into a new approach to designing material arrays having other kinds of effects on waves, such as a high number of resonant frequencies and strong focussing.

The work on multilinear generalized Radon transforms (and more general operators) was largely motivated by applications to geometric configurations: understanding whether, or how often, copies of collections of points (such as the vertices of a triangle) or geometric quantities (such as the volume determined by 4 points in 3-space) occur when the points are sampled from a particular set, E. A typical result says that if E has a high enough dimension, then the set of geometric configurations or quantities it determines is large.
The exact meaning of `high enough' and `large' varies from theorem to theorem.

Broader impact: Transformation optics has the potential, if the actual materials used to implement theoretical designs continue to improve, to result in devices having unusual and useful effects on various kinds of waves. The theoretical/numerical work supported by the project supplies another possible class of such devices. The study of geometric configurations might appear to be purely of mathematical interest, but in fact comes up in computer science and is widely studied there, and the approaches to these problems in the work supported by the Project open up new avenues of research.
